evaluations.message: Everyone knows Scout is unreliable. What they miss: she's unreliable in OPPOSITE directions. Child-Scout understands too little. Adult-Scout reveals too much. That tension IS the book.

justifications.memorable: The 'opposite directions' concept is vivid and concrete - students can easily remember 'too little vs too much'
justifications.differentiating: Reframes 'unreliable narrator' criticism into a feature, not a bug - most guides treat Scout's inconsistency as a problem
justifications.pattern_anchored: The bidirectional unreliability IS the core dynamic - can't understand this without seeing the retrospective narration pattern
justifications.funnel_continuous: Hook: 'opposite directions' mystery. Solution: full explanation of how retrospective narration creates this effect

evaluations.solution_register: The Maturing Moral Witness pattern creates bidirectional unreliability through retrospective narration - child consciousness understands too little, adult consciousness reveals too much.

winner.core_message: The Scout Paradox - How One Character Breaks Every Narration Rule (And Why It Works)
winner.why_it_wins: This thread scored highest (37/40) because it perfectly balances all four criteria. It's maximally memorable with 'Scout Paradox' and the concrete 'knows too much and too little' formulation. It's highly differentiating by positioning Scout as rule-breaking rather than flawed. It's completely pattern-anchored - the paradox IS the Maturing Moral Witness pattern's core dynamic. And it has perfect funnel continuity: the hook is the mysterious paradox, the solution is how retrospective narration creates this effect systematically. The 'paradox' framing works equally well as a social media tease ('Everyone knows Scout is unreliable in OPPOSITE directions') and as a comprehensive guide framework ('How the Maturing Moral Witness Pattern Creates Systematic Bidirectional Unreliability').
winner.agitation_register: The Scout Paradox: She simultaneously knows too much and too little - breaking every narration rule
winner.solution_register: The Maturing Moral Witness pattern explains how retrospective narration creates systematic bidirectional unreliability - child consciousness understands too little while adult consciousness reveals too much, creating the unique dual consciousness reading experience
winner.kernel_pattern_reference: The paradox IS the core dynamic: 'First-person retrospective narration filters adult moral understanding through remembered childhood innocence, creating dramatic irony between child-Scout's limited comprehension and adult-Scout's ethical clarity'
